tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating a vector perpendicular to two given vectors, which involves cross product and potentially normalization. It's a multi-step calculation but doesn't involve complex concepts or derivations.

answer_validation.reasoning: A vector perpendicular (orthogonal) to two given non-parallel vectors in 3D space must be parallel to their cross product. Option D gives the unit vector in the direction of v1 × v2, which is perpendicular to both. Options A and C yield vectors in the plane spanned by v1 and v2 (they are orthogonal to one of the vectors but not both). Option B (k) is orthogonal to v1 but not to v2. This aligns with the definition of the cross product from retrieved knowledge (Chunks 1 & 2).

step_by_step: Step 1: Understand the problem. We need a vector v3 perpendicular (orthogonal) to both v1 = i + 3j and v2 = 2i - 4j + 3k. Orthogonality means the dot product with each must be zero: v3·v1 = 0 and v3·v2 = 0.
Step 2: Recall the fundamental property: The cross product of two vectors, v1 × v2, yields a vector perpendicular to both. Any scalar multiple of this cross product is also perpendicular.
Step 3: Evaluate each option. Option A: v1 - (v1·v2)v2/|v2| is the component of v1 orthogonal to v2 (Gram-Schmidt step). It is orthogonal to v2 but not necessarily to v1. So fails.
Step 4: Option B: v3 = k. Check dot products: k·v1 = 0 (since v1 has no k component) but k·v2 = 3 ≠ 0. So fails.
Step 5: Option C: v2 - (v1·v2)v1/|v1| is the component of v2 orthogonal to v1. Orthogonal to v1 but not to v2. Fails.

Step 6: Option D: v3 = (v1 × v2) / |v1 × v2|. This is the unit vector in the direction of the cross product. By definition, v1 × v2 is perpendicular to both v1 and v2, and normalization doesn't change direction. Hence correct.

textbook_references.author: Shames
textbook_references.text_snippet: The cross product (or vector product) of two vectors a and b is another vector that is perpendicular to both a and b. Its magnitude is equal to the product of the magnitudes of the two vectors and the sine of the angle between them, and its direction is determined by the right-hand rule.

common_mistakes.mistake: Choosing option A or C, thinking it gives orthogonal vector to both.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusing the Gram-Schmidt process (which yields a vector orthogonal to one of the vectors) with the requirement of orthogonality to both.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: Gram-Schmidt produces an orthogonal basis step-by-step, but the vector orthogonal to both original vectors simultaneously is their cross product, not a linear combination.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming any vector orthogonal to one is automatically orthogonal to the other (e.g., picking k because v1 has no k component).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Incomplete checking; not verifying dot product with both vectors.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always test orthogonality condition with both given vectors: compute v3·v1 and v3·v2.
common_mistakes.consequence: Option B seems tempting but fails v2·k = 3 ≠ 0.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting that cross product yields a perpendicular vector, but then selecting an unnormalized cross product (not an option here).
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Read options carefully: D is the normalized cross product (unit vector). The question asks for 'the vector v3'—normalization is part of the expression.
common_mistakes.consequence: Might hesitate but still choose D as it's the only cross product option.

flashcards.front: What operation yields a vector perpendicular to two given vectors in 3D?
flashcards.back: The cross product (vector product). Its direction is given by the right-hand rule, and magnitude = |a||b|sinθ.

flashcards.front: Is the vector v1 - proj_{v2}(v1) orthogonal to both v1 and v2?
flashcards.back: No. It is orthogonal only to v2. To be orthogonal to both, you need the cross product.

flashcards.back: Torque calculation: τ = r × F, where r is position vector from pivot to force application point, and τ is the torque vector perpendicular to both.

real_world_context.industry_example: Aileron deflection creates a torque about the roll axis: the position vector from aircraft CG to aileron center of pressure crossed with the aerodynamic force vector yields the rolling moment.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Correct computation of moments is critical for stability and control analysis.

real_world_context.industry_example: Angular momentum of a satellite: h = r × v, where r is position vector from center of Earth, v is velocity vector. h is perpendicular to the orbital plane.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Conservation of angular momentum determines orbital orientation and stability.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Quickly recognize cross product as the key; eliminate options that are linear combinations of given vectors (A, C) and check option B with dot products. Should take < 2 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, remember that the cross product is the standard tool for 'perpendicular to both'; D is the only option containing cross product.
exam_strategy.time_management: Budget ~1.5 minutes for this 1-mark question with negative marking.

alternative_methods.name: Solve system of dot product equations
alternative_methods.description: Let v3 = ai + bj + ck. Set v3·v1 = 0 and v3·v2 = 0 to get two equations. Solve for ratios a:b:c (one free parameter). The solution is proportional to the cross product.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Systematic, always works. Cons: More time-consuming, requires solving linear system.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: If cross product formula is forgotten, or to verify.

connections_to_other_subjects.connection_3: Cross product appears in equations of motion for rotating bodies (Euler's equations).

deeper_dive_topics: Generalization to higher dimensions: In n-dimensional space, the orthogonal complement of a two-dimensional subspace is (n-2)-dimensional.
Cross product duality via skew-symmetric matrix: a × b = [a]_× b, where [a]_× is the skew-symmetric matrix of a.
Geometric algebra approach: wedge product and bivectors.
